items.name: C++
items.ask3: Avoid the use of macros when possible
items.ask4: Efficient use of types and data structures
items.ask15: Use of RAII (Resource Acquisition Is Initialization)
items.ask16: Proper use of std::unique_ptr and std::shared_ptr for pointer management
items.q1:
Classes and structures:
Use PascalCase for classes (class MyClass) and camelCase for members and methods (myVariable, myMethod()).
items.q2:
Variables:
Use camelCase for local variables and descriptive names. Avoid single-letter names unless in loops (i, j, etc.).
items.q3:
Smart Pointers:
Use smart pointers like std::unique_ptr, std::shared_ptr, and std::weak_ptr instead of raw pointers to manage memory more safely and automatically.
items.q4:
RAII (Resource Acquisition Is Initialization):
Use the RAII pattern to ensure resources are released when objects go out of scope.
items.q5:
Prefer constants and inline functions:
Use const, constexpr, or inline instead of macros for constants and functions.
items.q6:
Proper use of #define:
If you need macros, use clear prefixes and ensure they are unique to avoid name collisions.
items.q7:
Standard data structures:
Use the Standard Template Library (STL) collections such as std::vector, std::list, std::map, etc., instead of implementing your own structures.
items.q8:
STL Iterators and Algorithms:
Use STL iterators and algorithms for operations on containers rather than writing manual loops.
items.q9:
Separate declaration and definition:
Define functions and methods in .cpp files and declare classes and methods in .h files. This improves maintainability and code reuse.
items.q10:
Inline functions and classes:
Use inline for small functions that are frequently called, but don't overuse it as it may increase binary size.
items.q11:
Proper inheritance:
Use inheritance only when there is a clear 'is-a' relationship and employ polymorphism through base classes and virtual functions.
items.q12:
Favor composition over inheritance:
Prefer composition to inheritance whenever possible. It's better to have classes collaborate than to create complex inheritance hierarchies.
items.q13:
Avoid unnecessary copies:
Use references or pointers instead of passing large objects by value.
items.q14:
Move resources instead of copying:
Use move semantics instead of copying when possible. Implement move constructors and operators if your classes handle resources.
items.q15:
Function and class templates:
Use templates to create generic, reusable code. Templates allow you to write functions and classes that work with different data types.
items.q16:
Specialized templates:
When you need specific behavior for certain types, you can specialize templates.
items.q17:
Specific exceptions:
Use specific exceptions instead of catching all exceptions. Don’t use exceptions to control normal program flow.
items.q18:
Avoid new and delete in common code:
Prefer using smart pointers or functions that automatically manage memory to avoid the overhead of manual memory handling in general code.
items.q19:
Unit tests:
Implement unit tests with tools like Google Test or Catch2. Ensure that you test edge cases and common usage scenarios.
items.q20:
Use assert:
Use assert to check invariants or conditions that should not fail during normal program execution.
items.q21:
C++ Threads:
Use the standard thread library (<thread>) to manage concurrent tasks.
items.q22:
Futures and promises:
Use std::future and std::promise to handle asynchronous results instead of relying solely on direct threads.
items.q23:
Resource release:
Use std::unique_ptr or std::shared_ptr to ensure automatic release of memory and resources when no longer needed.
items.q24:
Use the Rule of Five:
If you implement one of the following: destructor, copy constructor, copy assignment, move constructor, or move assignment, implement all five to avoid resource handling errors.
items.q25:
Input validation:
Always validate user input to avoid security issues such as buffer overflows or injections.
items.q26:
Avoid unsafe functions:
Replace legacy C functions, such as strcpy, sprintf, with safer versions like strncpy and snprintf.
items.q27:
Code comments:
Use comments to describe the intention behind complex code blocks or non-trivial functions. Avoid redundant comments or those that describe the obvious.
items.q28:
Doxygen documentation:
Use tools like Doxygen to automatically generate documentation from structured comments in the code.
items.q29:
Automatic resource management:
The RAII pattern ensures that resources (memory, files, connections) are released automatically when an object goes out of scope. Use constructors and destructors to manage resource acquisition and release.
items.q30:
Avoid resource leaks:
RAII allows destructors to handle resource release, eliminating the need to manually manage it and reducing memory leaks or improperly released resources.
items.q31:
Smart pointers for automatic memory management:
Use std::unique_ptr when only one object should own a resource, and std::shared_ptr when multiple objects need to share ownership of a resource. This improves memory management and prevents leaks.
items.q32:
Error prevention with raw pointers:
Smart pointers (std::unique_ptr and std::shared_ptr) eliminate the need to manually release memory, reducing the risk of leaks and other errors associated with raw pointers.

items.name: Golang
items.ask2: Use of go fmt and style standards
items.ask4: Efficient concurrency handling with goroutines and channels
items.ask8: Avoid excessive use of global variables
items.ask9: Efficient use of collections and maps
items.q1:
Keep code simple and clear:
Go is designed to be simple. Avoid complex design patterns or advanced features that could make the code harder to understand. Simple, readable code is preferred over elegant but complicated code.
items.q3:
Code formatting:
Use go fmt to consistently format your code according to the language standards. This ensures that all code is readable and uniform, no matter who writes it.
items.q5:
Don't use exceptions:
Go doesn't have exceptions like other languages (Java, Python). Instead, error handling is done explicitly by returning an error value and checking it.
items.q7:
Goroutines:
Go has built-in concurrency with goroutines, which allow functions to be executed simultaneously in an efficient manner. They are lighter than traditional threads.
items.q8:
Channels:
Use channels for safe communication between goroutines. Channels help avoid race conditions by synchronizing data access.
items.q9:
Simple interfaces:
Define small interfaces with a specific purpose. Avoid designing large or 'fat' interfaces that do not fit many uses.
items.q11:
Pointers for large structures or mutability:
Use pointers when you need to modify the original values of a variable or when working with large structures to avoid expensive copies.
items.q13:
Careful handling of nil:
Ensure that you properly handle nil values. Do not access fields or methods of nil values without checking them first, as it can cause a runtime panic.
items.q15:
Avoid global variables:
Global variables can cause issues in concurrent programs and make code harder to maintain. It's better to encapsulate state within structures or pass it as parameters.
items.q17:
Maps:
Use maps for key-value pairs and arrays ([]) for ordered sequences. Maps in Go are efficient and useful, but keep in mind that they are not concurrency-safe without additional protection.
items.q19:
Write unit tests:
Use go test to write and run unit tests. Go has built-in support for testing, making it easy to create tests without external tools.
items.q20:
Test coverage:
Use go test -cover to view the code coverage in your tests.
items.q21:
Defer for resource release:
Use defer to ensure that resources like files, connections, or locks are properly released after use. Code marked with defer runs at the end of the function.
items.q23:
Dynamic slices:
Use slices instead of arrays when you need a dynamic size. Slices provide a flexible, dynamic view of a portion of an array.
items.q25:
Comments for documentation:
Use comments to document functions, structures, and packages. Comments that begin with the function or type name can be automatically turned into documentation with godoc.
items.q27:
Modularization with packages:
Split your code into packages (package) for better organization and reusability. Use descriptive names for the packages and their functions.
items.q29:
Memory usage efficiency:
Go has a garbage collector, but it's important to optimize memory usage where possible. Avoid creating large structures in functions that run often or in goroutines that run concurrently.
items.q30:
Avoid unnecessary copies:
Use pointers when necessary to avoid copying large structures or data in functions.
items.q31:
Avoid panic and recover unless absolutely necessary:
Go allows you to throw errors with panic, but it should only be used in exceptional situations (such as unrecoverable errors). To handle errors safely, return error and use recover only when truly necessary.

items.name: Python
items.ask1: Follow The Python Philosophy (Zen Of Python)
items.ask4: Proper use of variables and data types
items.ask6: Avoid repeated code (DRY - Don’t Repeat Yourself)
items.q1:
Python has its own philosophy called the Zen of Python, which contains important guidelines for writing quality Python code. Some of the most notable principles are:

- Readability counts
- Explicit is better than implicit
- Simple is better than complex
- Exceptions should not pass silently (unless they are handled).

You can see these principles by typing 'import this' in the Python console.
items.q3:
Use descriptive names:
Assign clear and meaningful names to variables, functions, classes, and modules. Avoid cryptic abbreviations.
items.q4:
Useful comments:
Comment only where necessary to explain the why of something, not the what the code does.
items.q5:
Indentation:
Use 4 spaces per indentation level. Do not use tabs.
items.q6:
Spacing around operators:
Leave a space around operators (=, +, -, etc.) to improve readability.
items.q7:
Dynamic typing and optional static typing:
Although Python is dynamically typed, you can use type hints to specify expected types in functions and variables, which improves clarity and eases maintenance.
items.q8:
Efficient collection handling:
Use the appropriate data structures (list, set, dict, tuple) as needed to optimize performance and code clarity.
items.q9:
Small and focused functions:
Each function should have a single responsibility (Single Responsibility Principle). Avoid large, monolithic functions.
items.q10:
Use default parameters and keyword arguments:
Use default values and named arguments to improve the flexibility and clarity of functions.
items.q11:
Modularization:
Break the code into reusable functions and modules to avoid logic duplication.
items.q12:
Use of classes and inheritance:
Utilize object-oriented programming when appropriate to encapsulate behavior and avoid code repetition.
items.q13:
Use try-except to handle errors:
Always handle potential errors with try-except blocks. Avoid letting exceptions go unnoticed.
items.q14:
Use finally for cleanup:
If you have code that needs to run regardless of whether an exception occurs, place it in a finally block.
items.q15:
List comprehensions:
Use list comprehensions to create new lists concisely and efficiently.
items.q16:
Generators:
Use generators (yield) to handle large amounts of data more efficiently without loading everything into memory.
items.q17:
Use with to handle files:
Use the with statement to open files and ensure they are properly closed.
items.q18:
Context managers:
Create your own context managers when you need to ensure that certain resources are properly released after use.
items.q19:
Unit tests:
Use the unittest module or frameworks like pytest to create unit tests that ensure your code works correctly.
items.q20:
Debugging:
Use pdb or built-in debugging tools in your code editor (like PyCharm or VSCode) to trace errors efficiently.
items.q21:
Virtual environments:
Use virtualenv or venv to isolate dependencies for each project. This prevents conflicts between library versions.
items.q22:
Requirements files or Pipfile:
Document project dependencies in a requirements.txt file or use Pipenv to manage dependencies efficiently.
items.q23:
Avoid nested loops and inefficient code:
Try to reduce the temporal and spatial complexity of your code. Use Python's native functions, such as map, filter, and reduce, when possible.
items.q24:
Profile the code:
Use tools like cProfile or timeit to analyze the performance of your code and identify bottlenecks.
items.q25:
Document your project with README and docstrings:
Use a README.md file to describe the purpose of the project, installation and usage instructions. Additionally, document your modules and functions using docstrings.
items.q26:
Generate automatic documentation:
Use tools like Sphinx to generate HTML documentation from docstrings.
items.q27:
Style conventions and linting tools:
Use linters like pylint or flake8 to ensure your code adheres to style conventions and is free from potential errors.
items.q28:
Code formatters:
Use tools like black or autopep8 to automatically format your code according to PEP 8.
items.q29:
Avoid the use of dangerous dynamic code:
Do not use eval() or exec() unless absolutely necessary, as they can be vulnerable to attacks.
items.q30:
Escape user inputs:
Always validate and escape user inputs, especially in web applications, to prevent attacks such as code injection.
items.q31:
Use asyncio and concurrent.futures when necessary:
To improve performance in programs that require intensive input/output operations or when you need to handle multiple tasks at once, use asyncio for asynchronous programming or concurrent.futures for parallelism.
items.q32:
Avoid blocking the main thread:
Proper use of these mechanisms allows your code to be more efficient without blocking the main flow of the program, improving performance in applications with many concurrent requests, such as web servers.

items.name: JavaScript
items.q1:
Meaningful naming:
Use clear and descriptive names for variables, functions, classes, and constants. They should be easy to understand.
items.q2:
Use of ; (semicolon):
Although optional in many cases, its explicit use prevents possible errors with Automatic Semicolon Insertion (ASI).
items.q3:
Use const and let instead of var:
Use const when the variable will not change its value, and let when reassignment is necessary. Avoid using var, as it can lead to scope issues.
items.q4:
Early declaration:
Declare variables and constants at the beginning of blocks for clarity and to avoid possible errors.
items.q5:
Reusable functions:
Break the code into small, reusable functions instead of having monolithic functions.
items.q6:
Modularization:
Use modules (import/export) to separate functionalities into different files and promote reusability.
items.q7:
Single Responsibility Principle (SRP):
Ensure that each function, class, or module has a single responsibility, making the code easier to maintain and modify.
items.q8:
Design patterns:
Use patterns like MVC (Model-View-Controller) or MVVM to organize your code, especially in large projects.
items.q9:
Pure functions:
When possible, use pure functions, meaning those that have no side effects and always return the same result for the same arguments.
items.q10:
Arrow functions (=>):
Use arrow functions when you need to preserve the value of this, or when you have small and simple functions.
items.q11:
Avoid nested conditions:
Use flat conditions or early returns instead of nested conditionals to avoid complexity.
items.q12:
Switch and guard clauses:
Use switch to handle multiple cases, and guard clauses (early return) to improve function readability.
items.q13:
Use try-catch:
Use try-catch blocks to handle errors robustly, especially in asynchronous operations or code that may fail.
items.q14:
Data validation:
Validate input parameters in functions and ensure to handle invalid values.
items.q15:
Use async and await:
Since ES6, prefer using async/await to handle asynchronous code instead of promises or callbacks, which simplifies error handling and improves readability.
items.q16:
Error handling in promises:
Always ensure to catch errors with .catch() in promises and use try-catch when working with async/await.
items.q17:
Minimize direct DOM manipulation:
Interacting with the DOM is costly, so it is advisable to minimize the number of accesses or changes.
items.q18:
Event delegation:
Instead of assigning events to multiple elements individually, use event delegation by assigning the event to a container element.
items.q19:
Avoid unnecessary loops:
Use methods like map(), filter(), and reduce() instead of for or while when appropriate, as they are more declarative and expressive.
items.q20:
Debouncing and Throttling:
Implement debouncing or throttling on intensive events like scroll or resize to improve performance.
items.q21:
Avoid memory leaks:
Ensure to clean up unused events or references, especially in long-running applications (e.g., removing event listeners).
items.q22:
Object lifecycle management:
Use objects and their references correctly, avoiding keeping unnecessary objects in memory.
items.q23:
Write unit tests:
Use frameworks like Jest or Mocha to write automated tests that ensure your code works as expected.
items.q24:
Use debugging tools:
Take advantage of debugging tools in browsers or development environments like Chrome DevTools or Visual Studio Code.
items.q25:
Clear and precise comments:
Comment only when necessary to explain the why of a decision in the code, not the what it does.
items.q26:
Documentation:
Use JSDoc or similar tools to document functions, classes, and parameters clearly.
items.q27:
Transpiling with Babel:
Use Babel to ensure your code is compatible with older versions of browsers or environments that do not support the latest ECMAScript features.
items.q28:
Polyfills:
Use polyfills to provide support for functionalities not implemented in older browsers.
items.q29:
Avoid using eval():
eval() can be dangerous as it executes dynamic code and can open security vulnerabilities.
items.q30:
Escaping user input:
Always escape user input to prevent injection attacks like XSS (Cross-Site Scripting).
items.q31:
NPM and Node.js:
Leverage the NPM ecosystem to manage dependencies and modules, and use Node.js to run JavaScript on the server side.
items.q32:
Webpack or Parcel:
Use module bundlers like Webpack or Parcel to efficiently manage the loading of your application’s resources.

items.name: PHP
items.ask4: Proper use of variables and constants
items.ask11: Use of Composer for dependency management
items.q1:
Descriptive names:
Use descriptive and clear names for variables and functions. Avoid confusing abbreviations and cryptic names.
items.q2:
Consistent code style:
Follow a coding convention like PSR-12 (PHP Standards Recommendations) that promotes uniform code style. Use camelCase for variables and methods, PascalCase for classes, and 4 spaces for indentation.
items.q3:
Small and concise functions:
Each function should have a single responsibility and do just one thing. This improves readability and makes unit testing easier.
items.q4:
Proper use of classes and objects:
PHP is an object-oriented language, so you should organize your code into classes where appropriate, utilizing concepts like inheritance, encapsulation, and composition.
items.q5:
MVC (Model-View-Controller):
Implement the MVC pattern to separate business logic, presentation layer, and database interaction. Use frameworks like Laravel or Symfony that implement this pattern.
items.q6:
Template systems for views:
Use template systems like Blade (in Laravel) or Twig to keep logic out of your views.
items.q7:
Local variables:
Declare variables in the smallest possible scope to reduce the risk of name conflicts.
items.q8:
Constants:
Use define or const to declare values that won't change throughout the program. Since PHP 5.3+, it's recommended to use const within classes.
items.q9:
Input validation:
Always validate user input. Use specific filters and functions like filter_var() to ensure data is of the expected type (integers, emails, URLs, etc.).
items.q10:
Sanitizing data:
Clean input data to prevent attacks such as Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) or SQL injection. Use htmlspecialchars() to escape output in views.
items.q11:
Use prepared statements:
Secure your database queries by using prepared statements with PDO or mysqli to prevent SQL injection.
items.q12:
Properly escape data:
If you cannot use prepared statements, escape input data using mysqli_real_escape_string() or equivalent functions.
items.q13:
Avoid deprecated functions:
Keep up with the latest PHP versions and avoid using obsolete functions like mysql_* in favor of mysqli or PDO.
items.q14:
Avoid eval():
Unless absolutely necessary, avoid eval() as it introduces critical vulnerabilities by executing arbitrary code.
items.q15:
Proper error handling:
Configure error reporting appropriately for development and production environments. In development, use error_reporting(E_ALL) to display all errors, and hide them in production using display_errors = Off.
items.q16:
Exceptions:
Use exceptions to handle critical errors. Avoid using die() or exit() to abruptly stop program execution.
items.q17:
Use require_once and include_once:
Use require_once or include_once to avoid multiple file inclusions, which can cause errors and reduce performance.
items.q18:
Optimize autoload:
Use spl_autoload_register() or Composer's autoloader to load classes automatically when needed.
items.q19:
Avoid unsafe file inclusion:
Never allow users to directly control what files are included. Use safe absolute or relative paths.
items.q20:
Secure session management:
Use session_regenerate_id() to prevent session hijacking and store sensitive session data securely.
items.q21:
Composer:
Use Composer to manage external dependencies in your project. This makes it easier to install, update, and manage external libraries, ensuring you are using the correct and secure versions of each dependency.
items.q22:
Autoloading:
Use Composer's autoloading feature to automatically load classes, avoiding the need to manually write require or include statements.
items.q23:
PHPUnit:
Use PHPUnit to write unit tests that verify your code works as expected. Automated tests improve code quality and make it easier to catch bugs.
items.q25:
Keep the code up to date:
Ensure that you are using a recent and compatible version of PHP. Older versions may have security vulnerabilities and lack performance improvements.
items.q27:
Protect against brute-force attacks:
Implement security measures like limiting login attempts and using secure hashes (e.g., bcrypt or Argon2) for passwords.
items.q29:
Improve code robustness:
PHP allows strict typing as of version 7, which helps prevent runtime errors by enforcing data type compliance. By enabling strict_types, you ensure function parameters and return values match the defined types.
items.q30:
Prevent automatic type conversion errors:
Using strict typing prevents automatic type conversions, making the code more predictable and reducing errors in functions expecting specific types.
items.q31:
Avoid name conflicts:
PHP 5.3 introduced namespaces, allowing you to organize code and avoid naming collisions, especially in large projects or when using many third-party libraries.
items.q32:
Enhance modularity and maintainability:
Namespaces help better organize classes and modules, making the code easier to maintain and preventing conflicts when integrating external libraries or working in large teams.

items.name: Java
items.ask3: Efficient use of collections and data structures
items.ask9: Proper use of concurrency and parallelism
items.ask10: Use of lambdas and streams (Java 8 and later)
items.ask16: Proper use of Optional (Java 8 and onwards)
items.q1:
Classes and methods:
Use clear and meaningful names. Class names should be in PascalCase and method names in camelCase.
items.q2:
Variables and constants:
Variables should follow camelCase and constants should be in uppercase with words separated by underscores (CONSTANT_EXAMPLE).
items.q3:
Inheritance:
Use inheritance only when there is a clear 'is a' relationship. If not, consider using composition.
items.q4:
Abstraction:
Hide the internal details of how the class works and expose only what is necessary to interact with it.
items.q5:
Choose the appropriate collection:
Use ArrayList, LinkedList, HashMap, TreeMap, HashSet, etc., depending on the use case. For example, HashMap is ideal for fast lookups, but TreeMap maintains order.
items.q6:
Generics:
Use generics to ensure type safety and avoid unnecessary casting. Example:
items.q7:
Avoid unnecessary object creation:
Do not create new objects when you can reuse them. Example: use StringBuilder or StringBuffer instead of concatenating Strings inside a loop.
items.q8:
Lazy initialization:
Use lazy initialization to load objects only when strictly necessary.
items.q9:
Use exceptions responsibly:
Use try-catch only where necessary. Avoid using exceptions to control the normal flow of the program.
items.q10:
Cleanup with finally:
Use finally to ensure that resources such as files or database connections are released properly.
items.q11:
Use of constructors:
Provide clear constructors and use the constructor pattern with parameters to efficiently initialize objects.
items.q12:
Immutable classes:
Create immutable classes whenever possible, especially if instances will be shared among multiple threads.
items.q13:
Follow the DRY principle (Don't Repeat Yourself):
Do not repeat code unnecessarily. If you have repeated logic, consider abstracting it into a method or class.
items.q14:
Use interfaces:
Define interfaces to promote reuse and flexibility. Classes should implement interfaces rather than relying on specific implementations.
items.q15:
Unit tests:
Use frameworks like JUnit to write unit tests that cover important cases in your code. These tests ensure that each component works in isolation.
items.q16:
Mocks:
Use tools like Mockito to simulate dependencies in unit tests and isolate the code you are testing.
items.q17:
Use of threads and concurrency:
Use threads only when necessary. If you are working in multi-threaded environments, ensure proper synchronization with synchronized, Locks, or tools from java.util.concurrent.
items.q18:
Executor framework:
Use the Executor Framework instead of manually managing threads for better resource management.
items.q19:
Lambda functions:
Use lambda expressions to simplify code, especially in collections and iteration handling.
items.q20:
Streams:
Use the Streams API to efficiently manipulate collections, facilitating operations like filtering, mapping, and reducing.
items.q21:
Resource release:
Use try-with-resources to ensure that resources such as files or database connections are automatically closed.
items.q22:
Garbage Collection:
Although Java handles memory automatically with garbage collection, avoid overhead by creating and destroying unnecessary objects.
items.q23:
Javadoc:
Use Javadoc to document your classes, methods, and attributes. This makes it easier for other developers (or yourself in the future) to understand the code without having to dive into its implementation.
items.q25:
Common patterns:
Familiarize yourself with design patterns such as Singleton, Factory, Observer, Builder, and Strategy, and apply them when appropriate to solve common software design problems.
items.q26:
Anti-design patterns:
Avoid anti-patterns like the 'God Object' (a class that does too much) or 'Spaghetti Code' (code without a clear structure and modularity).
items.q27:
Maven or Gradle:
Use dependency management tools like Maven or Gradle to handle third-party libraries and your project's dependencies.
items.q28:
Versioning:
Properly define the versions of your dependencies to avoid conflicts and ensure project stability.
items.q29:
Input validation:
Always validate user input to avoid code injection or security attacks.
items.q30:
Use secure libraries:
Keep dependencies updated and use trusted libraries to handle sensitive tasks like cryptography or database access.
items.q31:
Avoid null values:
Use the Optional class to avoid common errors related to null values and NullPointerExceptions. Optional allows you to explicitly represent that a variable may not have a present value instead of using null.
items.q32:
Avoid direct use of null:
Optional improves code clarity and safety by forcing the developer to handle the possibility of an absent value appropriately.

Small and specialized methods:

items.q4:

items.q5:
Handle exceptions properly:
Use try-catch only when necessary and catch specific exceptions rather than catch (Exception e).

Choose the right collection:

items.q8:
Use LINQ for efficient queries:
LINQ simplifies queries on collections and improves readability. Avoid unnecessary loops when you can use LINQ.
items.q9:
Separation of concerns (SoC):
Divide the logic of the code into layers (for example, presentation, business logic, and data access) so that each part has a single responsibility.
items.q10:
Use of interfaces and abstraction:
Define interfaces to allow for reuse and flexibility in implementation. Use abstraction when specific details are not necessary for the code user.
items.q11:

items.q12:
Composition over inheritance:
Whenever possible, prefer composition to inheritance, i.e., create smaller classes that collaborate with each other instead of creating deep inheritance hierarchies.
items.q13:
ingleton:
Use the “Singleton” pattern to ensure that a class has only one instance. Make sure it is “thread-safe” if used in a concurrent environment.
items.q14:
Factory and Dependency Injection:
Use the “Factory” pattern to create instances of objects and “Dependency Injection” to improve flexibility and maintainability of code.
items.q15:
Avoid null reference errors:
Use operators like “?.” (null conditional) to avoid null reference exceptions.
items.q16:
Null coalescing operator (”??”):

Using pattern:
Use the “using” block to handle automatic resource release for objects that implement the “IDisposable” interface (such as database connections, files, etc.).
items.q18:
Resource disposal:
Ensure that objects consuming resources (like database connections or streams) are closed or released appropriately.
items.q19:
Tasks and “async/await”:
Use “Task” and “async/await” to perform asynchronous tasks without blocking the main thread. This is especially useful in applications that require high responsiveness like web or desktop applications.
items.q20:
Multi-threading:
Use TPL (Task Parallel Library) or PLINQ to parallelize tasks without explicitly managing threads. Avoid manually handling threads if not necessary.
items.q21:
Delegates and Func/Action:
Use lambda expressions when you need to pass functions as parameters to other methods, or use the “Func<>” and “Action<>” types to simplify code.
items.q23:
Unit tests:
Use frameworks like “NUnit” or “xUnit” to create unit tests that ensure your code works correctly in isolation.
items.q24:
Mocking:
Use mocking frameworks like “Moq” to simulate dependencies and test your code independently.
items.q25:

Use XML documentation comments (”///”) to describe classes, methods, parameters, and return types. This not only improves readability but can also be used to generate documentation.
items.q27:
Use of NuGet packages:
Use “NuGet” to manage dependencies and external libraries. Properly define the versions of dependencies to avoid compatibility issues.
items.q28:
Dependency updates:
Keep your NuGet packages up to date, especially when it comes to security updates.
items.q29:
Use of safe libraries:
Use trusted libraries to handle tasks like cryptography or authentication.
items.q30:
Input validation:
Always validate user input to avoid attacks like SQL injection or XSS.
items.q31:
Optimization of asynchronous tasks:
In C#, using “async” and “await” allows for performing tasks that involve input/output operations (like database or network calls) without blocking the main thread. This improves the performance of applications that require multiple concurrent operations without blocking the user interface or main application flow.
items.q32:
Avoid thread blocking:
Using async and await correctly prevents thread blocking, improving efficiency and responsiveness, especially in graphical user interface applications or high-performance web services.

items.name: SQL
items.ask6: Proper handling of relationships between tables
items.ask8: Efficient use of GROUP BY and ORDER BY
items.ask14: Documentation and comments in SQL code
items.ask15: Use of subqueries and CTEs (Common Table Expressions)
items.q1:
Consistent use of uppercase and lowercase:
Use uppercase for SQL keywords and lowercase for table and column names, making queries more readable.
items.q2:
Indentation and organization of code:
Use line breaks and indentation to make queries easier to read. This is especially important in complex queries.
items.q3:
Proper structure:
Apply normalization principles to avoid data redundancy and improve integrity. The Third Normal Form (3NF) is generally sufficient for most cases:

- Ensure that tables do not have repeated data and that each field contains a single value
- Ensure that each column depends on the primary key
- Avoid dependencies between non-key columns.
items.q4:
Avoid over-relationship:
While normalization is essential, do not overly relate tables if it affects performance. In certain cases, denormalization can improve query efficiency.
items.q5:
Add indexes:
Indexes improve query performance by allowing the database to access data more quickly. Be sure to create indexes on columns that are frequently used in search conditions (WHERE), groupings (GROUP BY), ordering (ORDER BY), and joins (JOIN).
items.q6:
Composite indexes:
Use composite indexes when frequent queries involve multiple columns.
items.q7:
Avoid excessive use of SELECT *:
Only select the columns you really need. Using SELECT * can unnecessarily increase the load by returning data you don't need.
items.q8:
Proper use of JOIN:
Ensure that table joins (JOIN) are correct. Use the appropriate type of JOIN (INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN, FULL JOIN) according to the context.
items.q9:
Use transactions:
For operations involving multiple queries (such as inserts or updates across multiple tables), use transactions to ensure that all operations complete successfully or none apply. Use COMMIT to confirm the transaction or ROLLBACK to undo changes in case of error.
items.q10:
Ensure atomicity:
Transactions ensure that a set of operations executes as a unit. If any part fails, all operations performed are undone.
items.q11:
Foreign keys:
Use foreign keys to maintain referential integrity between tables. This ensures that data in one table correctly corresponds to related data in another.
items.q12:
Proper use of relationships:
If relationships between tables are hierarchical or have complex dependencies, ensure that you define the appropriate keys and constraints to avoid inconsistencies.
items.q13:
Prepared parameters:
Use parameterized queries to avoid SQL injections. Avoid directly concatenating user inputs into queries.
items.q14:
Properly escape data:
If not using prepared queries, ensure you properly escape user inputs.
items.q15:
Grouping and ordering:
Avoid grouping or ordering large volumes of data unnecessarily. Use indexes on columns that are frequently used in GROUP BY and ORDER BY to improve performance.
items.q17:
NULL conditions:
Columns that contain NULL values should be treated carefully in queries. Use IS NULL or IS NOT NULL instead of = to check for null values.
items.q19:
Efficient database design:
Ensure that data is not unnecessarily repeated. Use foreign keys and appropriate relationships to avoid information duplication.
items.q20:
Default values:
Define appropriate default values for columns that might not receive an explicit value during insertion.
items.q21:
Views to simplify complex queries:
Use views to encapsulate complex queries and facilitate access to data from multiple tables without having to write a complex query every time.
items.q22:
Limitations of views:
Keep in mind that some views can be slow if not well-optimized. Ensure that views do not introduce performance issues.
items.q23:
Aggregate functions:
Use functions like COUNT(), SUM(), AVG(), MAX(), MIN() to perform operations on groups of data.
items.q24:
Use HAVING:
Use HAVING to filter results after performing an aggregation.
items.q25:
Explain the execution plan:
Use the EXPLAIN command or its equivalent in your database system to see the execution plan of a query and understand how the database is processing the query.
items.q26:
Optimization based on the execution plan:
If you see that a query is performing a full table scan, consider adding indexes or restructuring the query.
items.q27:
Clear comments:
Document SQL queries to describe their purpose, especially if they are complex. Use comments in SQL using -- or /* */ to annotate key parts of the code.
items.q29:
Improving readability and organization:
Subqueries and CTEs allow structuring complex queries by breaking the work into more manageable parts. CTEs, in particular, introduced with the WITH clause, facilitate reusing intermediate results within the same query.
items.q30:
Improving performance in complex queries:
CTEs can improve clarity and performance compared to nested subqueries, allowing for result reuse and better organization of SQL queries.
items.q31:
Specify the necessary columns:
Using SELECT * may be tempting, but it is a bad practice as it can negatively impact performance, especially if you do not need all the columns from a table. Additionally, if new columns are added to a table, SELECT * could extract unwanted data.
items.q32:
Improve efficiency and clarity:
By specifying only the necessary columns, you reduce bandwidth consumption and speed up query response time, especially in large databases.

items.name: Python
items.ask1: Follow The Python Philosophy (Zen Of Python)
items.ask4: Proper use of variables and data types
items.ask6: Avoid repeated code (DRY - Don’t Repeat Yourself)
items.q1: Python has its own philosophy called the Zen of Python, which contains important guidelines for writing quality Python code. Some of the most notable principles are: readability counts, explicit is better than implicit, simple is better than complex, and exceptions should not pass silently (unless they are handled). You can see these principles by typing 'import this' in the Python console.
items.q3:
Use descriptive names:
Assign clear and meaningful names to variables, functions, classes, and modules. Avoid cryptic abbreviations.
items.q4:
Useful comments:
Comment only where necessary to explain the why of something, not the what the code does.
items.q5:
Indentation:
Use 4 spaces per indentation level. Do not use tabs.
items.q6:
Spacing around operators:
Leave a space around operators (=, +, -, etc.) to improve readability.
items.q7:
Dynamic typing and optional static typing:
Although Python is dynamically typed, you can use type hints to specify expected types in functions and variables, which improves clarity and eases maintenance.
items.q8:
Efficient collection handling:
Use the appropriate data structures (list, set, dict, tuple) as needed to optimize performance and code clarity.
items.q9:
Small and focused functions:
Each function should have a single responsibility (Single Responsibility Principle). Avoid large, monolithic functions.
items.q10:
Use default parameters and keyword arguments:
Use default values and named arguments to improve the flexibility and clarity of functions.
items.q11:
Modularization:
Break the code into reusable functions and modules to avoid logic duplication.
items.q12:
Use of classes and inheritance:
Utilize object-oriented programming when appropriate to encapsulate behavior and avoid code repetition.
items.q13:
Use try-except to handle errors:
Always handle potential errors with try-except blocks. Avoid letting exceptions go unnoticed.
items.q14:
Use finally for cleanup:
If you have code that needs to run regardless of whether an exception occurs, place it in a finally block.
items.q15:
List comprehensions:
Use list comprehensions to create new lists concisely and efficiently.
items.q16:
Generators:
Use generators (yield) to handle large amounts of data more efficiently without loading everything into memory.
items.q17:
Use with to handle files:
Use the with statement to open files and ensure they are properly closed.
items.q18:
Context managers:
Create your own context managers when you need to ensure that certain resources are properly released after use.
items.q19:
Unit tests:
Use the unittest module or frameworks like pytest to create unit tests that ensure your code works correctly.
items.q20:
Debugging:
Use pdb or built-in debugging tools in your code editor (like PyCharm or VSCode) to trace errors efficiently.
items.q21:
Virtual environments:
Use virtualenv or venv to isolate dependencies for each project. This prevents conflicts between library versions.
items.q22:
Requirements files or Pipfile:
Document project dependencies in a requirements.txt file or use Pipenv to manage dependencies efficiently.
items.q23:
Avoid nested loops and inefficient code:
Try to reduce the temporal and spatial complexity of your code. Use Python's native functions, such as map, filter, and reduce, when possible.
items.q24:
Profile the code:
Use tools like cProfile or timeit to analyze the performance of your code and identify bottlenecks.
items.q25:
Document your project with README and docstrings:
Use a README.md file to describe the purpose of the project, installation and usage instructions. Additionally, document your modules and functions using docstrings.
items.q26:
Generate automatic documentation:
Use tools like Sphinx to generate HTML documentation from docstrings.
items.q27:
Style conventions and linting tools:
Use linters like pylint or flake8 to ensure your code adheres to style conventions and is free from potential errors.
items.q28:
Code formatters:
Use tools like black or autopep8 to automatically format your code according to PEP 8.
items.q29:
Avoid the use of dangerous dynamic code:
Do not use eval() or exec() unless absolutely necessary, as they can be vulnerable to attacks.
items.q30:
Escape user inputs:
Always validate and escape user inputs, especially in web applications, to prevent attacks such as code injection.
items.q31:
Use asyncio and concurrent.futures when necessary:
To improve performance in programs that require intensive input/output operations or when you need to handle multiple tasks at once, use asyncio for asynchronous programming or concurrent.futures for parallelism.
items.q32:
Avoid blocking the main thread:
Proper use of these mechanisms allows your code to be more efficient without blocking the main flow of the program, improving performance in applications with many concurrent requests, such as web servers.

items.name: JavaScript
items.q1:
Meaningful naming:
Use clear and descriptive names for variables, functions, classes, and constants. They should be easy to understand.
items.q2:
Use of ; (semicolon):
Although optional in many cases, its explicit use prevents possible errors with Automatic Semicolon Insertion (ASI).
items.q3:
Use const and let instead of var:
Use const when the variable will not change its value, and let when reassignment is necessary. Avoid using var, as it can lead to scope issues.
items.q4:
Early declaration:
Declare variables and constants at the beginning of blocks for clarity and to avoid possible errors.
items.q5:
Reusable functions:
Break the code into small, reusable functions instead of having monolithic functions.
items.q6:
Modularization:
Use modules (import/export) to separate functionalities into different files and promote reusability.
items.q7:
Single Responsibility Principle (SRP):
Ensure that each function, class, or module has a single responsibility, making the code easier to maintain and modify.
items.q8:
Design patterns:
Use patterns like MVC (Model-View-Controller) or MVVM to organize your code, especially in large projects.
items.q9:
Pure functions:
When possible, use pure functions, meaning those that have no side effects and always return the same result for the same arguments.
items.q10:
Arrow functions (=>):
Use arrow functions when you need to preserve the value of this, or when you have small and simple functions.
items.q11:
Avoid nested conditions:
Use flat conditions or early returns instead of nested conditionals to avoid complexity.
items.q12:
Switch and guard clauses:
Use switch to handle multiple cases, and guard clauses (early return) to improve function readability.
items.q13:
Use try-catch:
Use try-catch blocks to handle errors robustly, especially in asynchronous operations or code that may fail.
items.q14:
Data validation:
Validate input parameters in functions and ensure to handle invalid values.
items.q15:
Use async and await:
Since ES6, prefer using async/await to handle asynchronous code instead of promises or callbacks, which simplifies error handling and improves readability.
items.q16:
Error handling in promises:
Always ensure to catch errors with .catch() in promises and use try-catch when working with async/await.
items.q17:
Minimize direct DOM manipulation:
Interacting with the DOM is costly, so it is advisable to minimize the number of accesses or changes.
items.q18:
Event delegation:
Instead of assigning events to multiple elements individually, use event delegation by assigning the event to a container element.
items.q19:
Avoid unnecessary loops:
Use methods like map(), filter(), and reduce() instead of for or while when appropriate, as they are more declarative and expressive.
items.q20:
Debouncing and Throttling:
Implement debouncing or throttling on intensive events like scroll or resize to improve performance.
items.q21:
Avoid memory leaks:
Ensure to clean up unused events or references, especially in long-running applications (e.g., removing event listeners).
items.q22:
Object lifecycle management:
Use objects and their references correctly, avoiding keeping unnecessary objects in memory.
items.q23:
Write unit tests:
Use frameworks like Jest or Mocha to write automated tests that ensure your code works as expected.
items.q24:
Use debugging tools:
Take advantage of debugging tools in browsers or development environments like Chrome DevTools or Visual Studio Code.
items.q25:
Clear and precise comments:
Comment only when necessary to explain the why of a decision in the code, not the what it does.
items.q26:
Documentation:
Use JSDoc or similar tools to document functions, classes, and parameters clearly.
items.q27:
Transpiling with Babel:
Use Babel to ensure your code is compatible with older versions of browsers or environments that do not support the latest ECMAScript features.
items.q28:
Polyfills:
Use polyfills to provide support for functionalities not implemented in older browsers.
items.q29:
Avoid using eval():
eval() can be dangerous as it executes dynamic code and can open security vulnerabilities.
items.q30:
Escaping user input:
Always escape user input to prevent injection attacks like XSS (Cross-Site Scripting).
items.q31:
NPM and Node.js:
Leverage the NPM ecosystem to manage dependencies and modules, and use Node.js to run JavaScript on the server side.
items.q32:
Webpack or Parcel:
Use module bundlers like Webpack or Parcel to efficiently manage the loading of your application’s resources.

items.name: PHP
items.ask4: Proper use of variables and constants
items.ask11: Use of Composer for dependency management
items.q1:
Descriptive names:
Use descriptive and clear names for variables and functions. Avoid confusing abbreviations and cryptic names.
items.q2:
Consistent code style:
Follow a coding convention like PSR-12 (PHP Standards Recommendations) that promotes uniform code style. Use camelCase for variables and methods, PascalCase for classes, and 4 spaces for indentation.
items.q3:
Small and concise functions:
Each function should have a single responsibility and do just one thing. This improves readability and makes unit testing easier.
items.q4:
Proper use of classes and objects:
PHP is an object-oriented language, so you should organize your code into classes where appropriate, utilizing concepts like inheritance, encapsulation, and composition.
items.q5:
MVC (Model-View-Controller):
Implement the MVC pattern to separate business logic, presentation layer, and database interaction. Use frameworks like Laravel or Symfony that implement this pattern.
items.q6:
Template systems for views:
Use template systems like Blade (in Laravel) or Twig to keep logic out of your views.
items.q7:
Local variables:
Declare variables in the smallest possible scope to reduce the risk of name conflicts.
items.q8:
Constants:
Use define or const to declare values that won't change throughout the program. Since PHP 5.3+, it's recommended to use const within classes.
items.q9:
Input validation:
Always validate user input. Use specific filters and functions like filter_var() to ensure data is of the expected type (integers, emails, URLs, etc.).
items.q10:
Sanitizing data:
Clean input data to prevent attacks such as Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) or SQL injection. Use htmlspecialchars() to escape output in views.
items.q11:
Use prepared statements:
Secure your database queries by using prepared statements with PDO or mysqli to prevent SQL injection.
items.q12:
Properly escape data:
If you cannot use prepared statements, escape input data using mysqli_real_escape_string() or equivalent functions.
items.q13:
Avoid deprecated functions:
Keep up with the latest PHP versions and avoid using obsolete functions like mysql_* in favor of mysqli or PDO.
items.q14:
Avoid eval():
Unless absolutely necessary, avoid eval() as it introduces critical vulnerabilities by executing arbitrary code.
items.q15:
Proper error handling:
Configure error reporting appropriately for development and production environments. In development, use error_reporting(E_ALL) to display all errors, and hide them in production using display_errors = Off.
items.q16:
Exceptions:
Use exceptions to handle critical errors. Avoid using die() or exit() to abruptly stop program execution.
items.q17:
Use require_once and include_once:
Use require_once or include_once to avoid multiple file inclusions, which can cause errors and reduce performance.
items.q18:
Optimize autoload:
Use spl_autoload_register() or Composer's autoloader to load classes automatically when needed.
items.q19:
Avoid unsafe file inclusion:
Never allow users to directly control what files are included. Use safe absolute or relative paths.
items.q20:
Secure session management:
Use session_regenerate_id() to prevent session hijacking and store sensitive session data securely.
items.q21:
Composer:
Use Composer to manage external dependencies in your project. This makes it easier to install, update, and manage external libraries, ensuring you are using the correct and secure versions of each dependency.
items.q22:
Autoloading:
Use Composer's autoloading feature to automatically load classes, avoiding the need to manually write require or include statements.
items.q23:
PHPUnit:
Use PHPUnit to write unit tests that verify your code works as expected. Automated tests improve code quality and make it easier to catch bugs.
items.q25:
Keep the code up to date:
Ensure that you are using a recent and compatible version of PHP. Older versions may have security vulnerabilities and lack performance improvements.
items.q27:
Protect against brute-force attacks:
Implement security measures like limiting login attempts and using secure hashes (e.g., bcrypt or Argon2) for passwords.
items.q29:
Improve code robustness:
PHP allows strict typing as of version 7, which helps prevent runtime errors by enforcing data type compliance. By enabling strict_types, you ensure function parameters and return values match the defined types.
items.q30:
Prevent automatic type conversion errors:
Using strict typing prevents automatic type conversions, making the code more predictable and reducing errors in functions expecting specific types.
items.q31:
Avoid name conflicts:
PHP 5.3 introduced namespaces, allowing you to organize code and avoid naming collisions, especially in large projects or when using many third-party libraries.
items.q32:
Enhance modularity and maintainability:
Namespaces help better organize classes and modules, making the code easier to maintain and preventing conflicts when integrating external libraries or working in large teams.

items.name: TypeScript
items.ask6: Proper use of classes and inheritance
items.ask7: Avoid excessive use of type coercion
items.ask8: Proper handling of null and undefined
items.ask10: Keep the code clean and readable
items.ask12: Implement flow control with type discrimination
items.ask15: Proper use of readonly and const
items.q1:
Define types explicitly:
Leverage TypeScript's type system to define clear and specific types. This helps catch errors at compile time rather than runtime.
items.q2:
Use interface and type for complex structures:
Define interfaces or types to describe the shape of objects and other complex data types.
items.q3:
Avoid excessive use of any:
Avoid using any whenever possible, as it disables type checking and negates one of TypeScript's main advantages.
items.q5:
Enums:
Enums allow you to define a set of named constant values. This improves code readability and compile-time safety.
items.q7:
Import and export modules:
Split your code into reusable and maintainable modules. Use import and export keywords to share functions, classes, or constants across files.
items.q9:
Async/await:
Use async and await to handle asynchronous operations in a more readable way and avoid excessive nested promises.
items.q10:
Handle asynchronous errors:
Always wrap asynchronous operations in try/catch blocks to capture and handle errors.
items.q11:
Classes and inheritance:
TypeScript offers full support for object-oriented programming. Use classes to create reusable structures and apply principles like inheritance and encapsulation.
items.q13:
Safe types:
Avoid forced type conversion (coercion).
If you need to change a type, use the appropriate methods and tools to ensure safe conversion.
items.q15:
Handle null values:
Use the ! and ? operators to properly manage null or undefined values and avoid reference errors.
items.q17:
Interfaces:
Use interfaces to describe the shape of an object, especially in cases where you expect it to be extended or implemented by classes.
items.q18:
Type:
Use type when defining complex types like unions, intersections, or aliases.
items.q19:
Linting and formatting:
Use tools like TSLint or ESLint along with Prettier to ensure your code follows consistent style and best practices.
items.q20:
Proper naming:
Use descriptive and meaningful names for variables, functions, and classes. This improves code comprehension.
items.q21:
Generic types:
Use generics to create functions and classes that can work with different types while maintaining type safety.
items.q23:
Type guards:
Use type guards to handle objects of different types correctly and avoid runtime errors.
items.q25:
Compilation settings:
Properly configure the tsconfig.json file to control aspects like strict type checking (strict: true), support for ES6 or later, and input/output directories for compiled files.
items.q27:
Unit testing with TypeScript:
Write unit tests using tools like Jest or Mocha. Combining unit testing with TypeScript’s type system ensures your code works properly and is easy to maintain.
items.q29:
Immutability:
Use the readonly keyword to ensure data is not modified after assignment, especially in objects and arrays.
items.q31:
Type inference:
TypeScript can infer types in many cases, so it’s not always necessary to explicitly specify the type. Let the compiler handle it when types are obvious.

items.name: Swift
items.ask13: Proper use of structures and classes
items.ask15: Use of guard to avoid nesting
items.ask16: Avoid using complex logic inside closures
items.q1:
Meaningful naming:
Use descriptive names for variables, functions, and classes. This facilitates code readability and understanding.
items.q2:
Proper spacing and indentation:
Maintain consistent indentation (usually 4 spaces) and logically group the code.
items.q3:
Use let and var properly:
Declare variables with let if they don't change, and with var if they might.
This helps optimize memory.
items.q4:
Avoid strong captures in closures:
Use [weak self] or [unowned self] in closures to avoid reference cycles that can cause memory leaks.
items.q5:
Follow the DRY (Don’t Repeat Yourself) principle:
Avoid duplicating code by creating reusable functions and separating logic into different modules or classes.
items.q6:
Use Protocols:
Swift protocols allow defining interfaces and promote code reuse and interface-oriented programming.
items.q7:
Leverage Swift's type system:
Swift is strongly typed, so using safe types like Optionals and Generics prevents errors and enhances robustness.
items.q8:
Handle Optionals:
Use if let, guard let, or the ?? operator to safely unwrap Optionals, preventing potential crashes.
items.q9:
Error handling with do-catch:
Swift provides a robust error handling system. Use throws and do-catch to manage errors clearly and efficiently.
items.q10:
Validation and preconditions:
Use assert or precondition to validate critical assumptions that could affect program execution.
items.q11:
Comments and documentation:
Write clear comments when the code may be difficult to understand. Use /// for documenting functions and classes.
items.q12:
Clean code:
Remove dead or unused code, avoid unnecessary comments, and follow style conventions like those recommended by Apple.
items.q13:
Unit testing:
Use unit tests to verify your code works correctly and to ensure changes don’t introduce errors.
items.q14:
Efficient debugging:
Use Xcode’s debugging tools, such as breakpoints and logging, to quickly identify and fix errors.
items.q15:
Extensions:
Use extensions to add functionality to existing types without modifying their original implementation, keeping the code modular and clean.
items.q17:
ARC (Automatic Reference Counting):
ARC automatically manages memory by releasing objects when they’re no longer needed. Strong references are the default and keep objects alive as long as there are references to them. However, this can cause reference cycles if two objects reference each other, which leads to memory leaks.
items.q18:
Lazy properties:
Use lazy properties when a value is not immediately needed to improve program efficiency.
items.q19:
Follow SOLID principles:
Apply object-oriented design principles to ensure your code is easy to maintain and scale.
items.q20:
Use design patterns like Singleton, MVC, and MVVM:
These patterns help organize the code and make it more flexible and maintainable.
items.q21:
GCD (Grand Central Dispatch) and Operation Queues:
Take advantage of Swift’s concurrency capabilities using GCD to run background tasks and improve application performance.
items.q22:
Async/await:
From Swift 5.5, you can use async and await to handle asynchronous code in a more clear and structured way.
items.q23:
Swift API Design Guidelines:
Following Swift’s official naming and style guidelines ensures your code aligns with the language’s best practices.
items.q25:
Choose between struct and class wisely:
Use struct for types that don't need inheritance and should be copied when passed between functions, and class when you need inheritance or want to manage references.
items.q26:
Immutability in struct:
Structs are immutable if declared as constants, improving code safety.
items.q27:
Control access with access modifiers:
Use access modifiers (private, fileprivate, internal, public, open) to encapsulate data and ensure properties or methods are only accessible from where they should be.
items.q28:
Avoid excessive use of public:
Limit the visibility of variables and methods to prevent unnecessary exposure.
items.q29:
Use guard to exit early:
Employ guard to avoid excessive nesting and clarify the conditions under which a function should continue executing.
items.q30:
Greater clarity in conditions:
'guard' makes error conditions or exceptions clear and easy to spot.
items.q31:
Keep closures simple:
Closures should be short and easy to understand. Avoid placing complex logic within them.
items.q32:
Extract complex logic:
If you need to implement more complicated logic, it's better to extract it into a separate function.

var variable = 20 // Can change
variable = 30

precondition(number > 0, "The number must be greater than 0")
print("Valid number")
